title: Notice of A Home in Africa - identify process

content.description:
Announcement of the Universal Negro Improvement Association Calling for Members to Settle in Liberia, West Africa

The document reads as follows:

“Let’s Put it Over.”

A Home in Africa.

Notice to Members of Universal Negro Improvement Association.

All members of the Universal Negro Improvement Association who desire to go to Liberia, West Africa, to settle to help in the industrial, commercial and cultural development of the country, and who intend sailing September, October, December, 1924, or January, February, March, April or May, 1925, are requested to send in for application form to be filled out.

Address: Universal Negro Improvement Assn., Dept. E, 56 West 135th Street, New York City, USA.
The Marcus Garvey and UNIA Papers Project
content.question: The source best supports which of the following ideas about the mission of the Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA)?

choices.label: The Universal Negro Improvement Association sought to unite Black people throughout North America, Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa.
Black intellectuals sought to open African free schools to connect Black children throughout the African diaspora.
The successes of the Great Migration were the founding principles of the Universal Negro Improvement Association.
The Universal Negro Improvement Association wanted to reduce tension between Afro-Caribbean immigrants and the African American community.

content.answer: The Universal Negro Improvement Association sought to unite Black people throughout North America, Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa.

skill.text: 1.B: Identify and explain the context of a specific event, development, or process.
